questions.text: In a diabetic patient, the following lesions are present in the armpit. What would be observed during a Wood's lamp examination? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coral red fluorescence.

 

  • The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient, along with the observed hyperpigmented lesion in axilla strongly suggests erythrasma.
  • Coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is the characteristic finding in this disease.

 

 

Erythrasma

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes and weakened immune systems and is associated with factors such as obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.
  • The characteristic feature of erythrasma is the presence of hyperpigmented patches that are typically asymptomatic. These patches commonly appear in areas like the axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub-mammary regions.
  • The coral pink fluorescence observed during Wood's lamp examination is a defining feature of erythrasma and is caused by coproporphyrin III, a pigment produced by the bacterium.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Yellow fluorescence: Often seen with Pityriasis versicolor, which fluoresces yellow or apple green due to the presence of tryptophan metabolites produced by Malassezia species.

 

Option C. Blue fluorescence: Not commonly associated with bacterial or fungal infections of the skin but may appear in certain conditions unrelated to common skin infections.

 

Option D. Green fluorescence: Typically observed with Pseudomonas infections or some cases of Tinea capitis caused by fungi that produce substances that fluoresce green.

 

Additional Information

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

questions.text: Given the particular appearance and characteristics of the box-whisker plot as shown below, which of the following statements most accurately describes the relationships between the mean, median, and mode? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mean > Median > Mode 

 

  • The provided box-whisker plot illustrates a distribution that is positively skewed (right skewed).
  • In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.
  • To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Right skew curve: Mean > Median > Mode
  • In Left skew curve: Mean < Median < Mode
  • In Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode.

questions.text: An infant came with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder characterized by the inability to metabolize galactose properly due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, resulting in symptoms such as vomiting, jaundice, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and oil droplet cataracts. The condition often presents in the neonatal period shortly after the introduction of milk or milk-based formulas, which contain lactose (broken down into glucose and galactose). The inability to process galactose leads to hypoglycemia due to disruption in normal glucose metabolism.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylketonuria: This condition involves a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels. Symptoms typically include intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty body odor, but not jaundice or hypoglycemia. There is no direct association with the symptoms of vomiting or jaundice seen in the presented case.

 

Option C. Wilson disease: Wilson disease is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation, particularly in the liver and brain. Key symptoms include hepatic dysfunction, neurological symptoms like tremors (wing-beating tremors), and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes. However, it does not typically present with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia in infancy.

 

Option D. Menke disease: Menke disease is a disorder of copper transport, characterized by kinky hair, growth failure, and deterioration of the nervous system. It does not typically present with jaundice or hypoglycemia. The defining symptoms such as brittle, kinky hair were not noted in the question, making it less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia should be suspected in infants presenting with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia, especially soon after the introduction of milk. Immediate dietary management with lactose-free formulas is critical to prevent complications.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company has developed a novel diagnostic test for a rare metabolic disorder. In clinical trials, the test demonstrated a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.80. In a population where the prevalence of the disease is 30%, the test was applied to every participant. What is the probability that a person who tests negative truly does not have the disease? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 95%

 

  • It’s the Negative Predictive Value (NPV), which tells us the probability that a person with a negative test result truly doesn't have the disease.

 NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

  • Use a hypothetical cohort of 1000 people for easy calculation.

 

Given:

 

  • Disease prevalence = 30% = 300 people with the disease and 700 without the disease out of 1000.
  • Sensitivity = 0.90, so TP = 0.90 * 300 = 270 and FN = 300 - 270 = 30.
  • Specificity = 0.80, so TN = 0.80 * 700 = 560 and FP = 700 - 560 = 140.

 

Using the above formula:

 

NPV = 560 / (560 + 30) = 560 / 590 = 0.9491 or approximately 95%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Negative Predictive Value (NPV) represents the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease

choices.text: At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent
Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body
Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits mullerian duct
Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about male sexual development? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

 

Explanation:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent. The term "bipotent" refers to the embryo's capability to develop into either male or female structures, which is true up until about the sixth week of development. By the eighth week, sexual differentiation is already underway, with the influence of the SRY gene causing the gonads to differentiate into testes in 46XY embryos. This differentiation results in a shift away from bipotency, making the embryo committed to developing male characteristics.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body: This statement is true. The Wolffian ducts, under the influence of testosterone, develop into the male reproductive structures including the epididymis and vas deferens.

 

Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct: This statement is true. Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS), also known as anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), is produced by Sertoli cells in the testes and inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female reproductive structures such as the uterine tubes and uterus.

 

Option D. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia: This statement is true. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent metabolite of testosterone, is crucial for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics such as facial hair and a deeper voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent; sexual differentiation has already commenced.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bath the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bath the baby with warm water immediately

     

Newborn care practices emphasize immediate and appropriate actions to ensure the health and safety of the infant. Bathing the baby immediately after birth is discouraged because the baby's skin needs to adapt to the new environment, and the vernix (a protective layer on the skin) should be allowed to remain on the skin for as long as possible to provide a barrier against infection. Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is generally not recommended, especially in settings where environmental conditions (such as warmth and cleanliness) are not optimal.

 

The recommended practice is to wait at least 24 hours and then start with gentle sponging until the umbilical cord falls off, typically within the first week of life. Only after this can full baths be introduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exclusive breastfeeding: This is the recommended feeding method for newborns, providing optimal nutrition and immunity support. It should be started within the first hour of birth.

 

Option C. Clean the eyes: Cleaning the eyes is a standard neonatal practice to prevent infection. This is part of routine newborn care and helps prevent neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact: Skin-to-skin contact is encouraged immediately after birth as it helps regulate the newborn's body temperature, promotes bonding, and supports breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended; it should be delayed until the umbilical cord falls off, and gentle sponging should be started after 24 hours to maintain hygiene and prevent hypothermia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. Ultrasound revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Papillary cancer of thyroid

 

The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

 

Histologically, the following features are present

 

  1. Papillary pattern - Papillae composed of fibrovascular stalk and covered by single layer of tumor cells is the predominant feature. Papillae are often accompanied by follicles.
  2. Tumor cells. The tumor cells have characteristic nuclear features due to dispersed nuclear chromatin imparting it ground glass or optically clear appearance and clear or oxyphilic cytoplasm also called Orphan Annie nuclei.
  3. Invasion - Invade the capsule and intra-thyroid lymphatics
  4. Psammoma bodies - Small, concentric, calcified spherules called psammoma bodies in the stroma.

 

Papillary carcinoma thyroid microscopy shows branching papillae having fibrovascular stalk covered by a single layer of cuboidal cells having ground nuclei. Colloid-filled follicles and sloid sheets of tumor cells are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary cancer of thyroid: This cancer arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histologically, it shows a solid growth pattern with amyloid deposits, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Follicular cancer of thyroid: This type of thyroid cancer typically shows a follicular growth pattern with invasion into blood vessels or the capsule. The cells do not have the distinct nuclear features (Orphan Annie nuclei) seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Thyroglossal cyst: This is a benign cystic lesion that usually presents as a midline neck mass that moves with swallowing or tongue protrusion. It does not present with a nodule in the thyroid gland or the histological features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by Orphan Annie nuclei, psammoma bodies, and a papillary architecture, which are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

choices.text: Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year

 

Correct sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year.

 

Normal length of a newborn - 48-50cm (increase by 50% at 1st year = 75cm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year: An infant gain weight at a rate of approximately 20-40 g per day for the first 3 months of life. Thereafter, they gain about 400 g weight every month for the remaining part of the first year.

 

Option C. Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age:

 

 

Option D. Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile: According to WHO growth charts, weight and height under 50th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in length by 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

questions.text: The latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period of a skeletal muscle are 10 ms, 40 ms, and 50 ms respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as - 1/contraction period.

 

In this problem, contraction period is 40msec = 0.04sec

 

So, Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanization-  As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called Tetanization.

questions.text: Which of the following defects causes familial hypercholesterolemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is primarily caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or Apo B100 protein. The LDL receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of cholesterol levels in the blood by mediating the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles into cells, particularly in the liver. When the LDL receptor is defective or absent, LDL particles cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated cholesterol levels, which predispose individuals to atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. This condition is also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E: Defects in Apo E are associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia, not familial hypercholesterolemia. Apo E is important for the clearance of chylomicron remnants and VLDL from the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Apo CII: Apo CII is an activator of lipoprotein lipase, which is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in lipoproteins. Deficiency in Apo CII leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial hyperchylomicronemia), characterized by elevated chylomicrons and triglycerides, not familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option D. Apo B48: Apo B48 is involved in the formation and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. It is not related to the development of familial hypercholesterolemia, which involves defects in the LDL receptor or related proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood and increased risk of atherosclerosis.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
  2. PT and APTT
  3. Bone marrow
  4. Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

 

The clinical presentation, along with the findings of the peripheral blood smear and a Mentzer index of less than 13, suggests a diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A hemoglobinopathy characterized by a deficiency in the synthesis of one of the globin chains, either alpha or beta. In beta-thalassemia, there is reduced synthesis of beta chains, leading to decreased levels of hemoglobin A (HbA) and increased levels of HbA2 and HbF.
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): This test is crucial for diagnosing thalassemia as it can detect changes in hemoglobin levels, specifically the increased levels of HbA2 and HbF that are characteristic of beta-thalassemia. HPLC is sufficient for diagnosis without the need for bone marrow investigations.
  • Peripheral Blood Smear: The smear may reveal aniso-poikilocytosis, target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells, which are indicative of thalassemia.
  • Mentzer Index: The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV/RBC count, helps differentiate thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia. A value of less than 13 suggests thalassemia, while a value greater than 13 suggests iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

2 (PT and APTT): These tests are not directly relevant for the diagnosis of thalassemia. PT (Prothrombin Time) is used to assess the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) assesses the intrinsic pathway, typically done when bleeding disorders are suspected.

 

3 (Bone Marrow): Bone marrow examination is not necessary in this case as the diagnosis of thalassemia can be made based on HPLC and peripheral smear findings. Bone marrow investigations are more appropriate for cases of pancytopenia or unexplained anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cell

 

The marked cell is Mast cell which is stained deep blue with Toluidine blue.

 

 

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and these cells are responsible for the allergic or hypersensitivity reactions.

 

When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulation occurs releasing various mediators like Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin, Lipid mediators (Leukotriene C4, D4), prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor cytokines (TNF, IL 1).

questions.text:
172. Match the following tests and poisons:

 

Column-A

1. Marsh test

2. Silver nitrate paper test

3. Cavett test

4. Marqui's test

 

Column-B

a. Opium

b. Aluminium phosphide

c. Alcohol

d. Arsenic
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 → d, 2 → b, 3 → c, 4 → a

 

1. Marsh test → Arsenic (d): The Marsh test is a well-known, traditional method for detecting arsenic poisoning. It generates arsine gas, which decomposes to produce metallic arsenic stains, confirming the presence of arsenic.

 

2. Silver nitrate paper test → Aluminium phosphide (b): This test is used to detect aluminium phosphide poisoning. When aluminium phosphide reacts with moisture, it releases phosphine gas. The phosphine turns silver nitrate paper black, indicating a positive result.

 

3. Cavett test → Alcohol (c): The Cavett test is a micro-method for determining blood alcohol levels. It works on the principle that alcohol reduces potassium bichromate. For forensic purposes, gas chromatography is often preferred for accurate measurement.

 

4. Marqui's test → Opium (a): Marqui's test is used to detect opium. When a suspected opium sample is treated with concentrated sulfuric acid and formalin, a color change from purple-red to violet and finally to blue occurs, indicating the presence of opium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Marsh test detects arsenic.
  • Silver nitrate paper test detects aluminium phosphide.
  • Cavett test is for alcohol detection.
  • Marqui's test detects opium.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atropine Sulfate eye ointment

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in both bacterial as well as a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is utilized in the management of fungal corneal ulcers primarily to relieve symptoms like pain due to ciliary spasm and to prevent complications such as the formation of posterior synechiae. Atropine achieves this by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscles, thus providing a therapeutic benefit in the treatment of corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine e/d: Generally used to contract the pupil in glaucoma treatment, not appropriate for corneal ulcers as it can increase pain by causing ciliary spasm.

 

Option B. Lignocaine e/d: An anesthetic used for temporary pain relief but does not serve as adjuvant therapy in managing ulcers.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone e/d: A corticosteroid, generally avoided in fungal infections due to its potential to exacerbate infections by suppressing immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcers to relieve pain and prevent the formation of posterior synechiae by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscle.

questions.text: The following image indicates: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor palsy

 

The given image suggests oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements, it can be seen that adduction, elevation, and depression are absent in the left eye.

 

All of these findings indicate oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis: This is due to the weakness of the levator muscle.
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out"): This is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest: This is due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction: This is due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation: This is due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression: This is due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation: This is due to parasympathetic palsy.
  • Normal abduction: This is due to the intact lateral rectus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve palsy: Primarily affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia and head tilt but does not cause ptosis or pupil involvement.

 

Option B. Lateral rectus palsy: Would lead to medial deviation of the eye due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle, affecting horizontal eye movement.

 

Option C. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: Characterized by impairment of horizontal eye movements, particularly affecting the adduction of the eye on the side of the lesion, with nystagmus in the abducting eye, typically not involving the eyelid or pupil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor palsy involves multiple dysfunctions including ptosis, "down and out" eye position, and possibly a dilated pupil. Recognizing the full range of symptoms is critical for a correct diagnosis, indicating a comprehensive evaluation of cranial nerve III integrity.

questions.text: Primary follicles arrest in which phase of prophase 1? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diplotene

 

Primary follicles containing primary oocytes are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis. This arrest occurs before a female is born and remains until puberty. The mnemonic "PPD" can help remember this: Primary oocyte, Prophase I, Diplotene stage. After puberty, under hormonal influence during each menstrual cycle, selected primary oocytes resume meiosis, complete the first meiotic division to form secondary oocytes, and then arrest again at metaphase II until fertilization occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leptotene: Incorrect because leptotene is an earlier stage of prophase I where chromosomes begin to condense and become visible. Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Option B. Zygotene: Incorrect because zygotene is the stage where homologous chromosomes begin to pair up (synapsis). Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Option C. Pachytene: Incorrect because pachytene is the stage where crossing over (genetic recombination) occurs between homologous chromosomes. Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary oocytes remain arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis from before birth until puberty, resuming meiosis only when stimulated by hormones during the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.

 

Option C. Syphilis: A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 926

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele's rule? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) October 16

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day 
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 9 months and subtract 7 days from the date of the embryo transfer
  • For e.g. The EDD of this patient will be 16/10/2017.
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND.
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naegele's rule is a standard way of calculating the estimated date of delivery by adding 9 months and 7 days to the first day of the last menstrual period. This method assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 83, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

questions.text:
A couple has been attempting to conceive for the past two years with unprotected intercourse yet without success, the husband's semen analysis was ordered and results are as follows: 

 

  • Volume: 2ml
  • Viability: 75%
  • Sperm count: 40 million per ejaculate

 

The wife’s HSG report shows no abnormalities. What percentage of infertile women have unexplained infertility? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15%

 

In cases of infertility, the distribution of causes follows a specific pattern:

 

  • Female factor infertility: 40%
  • Male factor infertility: 30%
  • Combined male and female factors: 15%
  • Unexplained infertility: 15%

 

Unexplained infertility is diagnosed when:

 

  • Standard fertility tests are normal
  • No obvious cause is identified despite thorough evaluation
  • Tests showing normal results include: 
    • Ovulation tests
    • Tubal patency (HSG)
    • Uterine cavity evaluation
    • Semen analysis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unexplained infertility accounts for 15% of all infertility cases, while female factor accounts for 40%, male factor for 30%, and combined factors for 15%.

choices.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes
Clear colorless to pale yellow

questions.text: Which of the following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear colorless to pale yellow

 

Explanation:

 

The color of normal amniotic fluid varies during pregnancy and can indicate different conditions:

 

  • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless.
  • Near term: It becomes straw-colored.
  • Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia.
  • Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity.
  • Red: Suggests abruption.
  • Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.

 

Normal amniotic fluid should be clear, colorless, or pale yellow, especially in the earlier stages of pregnancy and near term when the fluid changes to a straw color.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes: This description is not characteristic of normal amniotic fluid. Such a color can indicate the presence of infection or contamination.

 

Option B. Amber colored: Amber-colored amniotic fluid is not a normal finding and may indicate complications such as the presence of blood or other abnormalities.

 

Option D. Golden color: Golden-colored amniotic fluid typically indicates fetal anemia, which is a pathological condition and not a feature of normal amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal amniotic fluid is clear, colorless to pale yellow, changing to straw-colored near term.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298

questions.text: A male baby born to a non-consanguineous couple develops blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also had similar complaints and died at the age of 2 weeks. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa 

 

The clinical history points to a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa congenita.

 

Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechanobullous disease characterized by blistering in areas of mechanical trauma. Blisters commonly appear on trauma-prone areas such as hands, feet, elbows, and knees. There are three types:

 

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex: Defective K5/K14 protein
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa: Defective Laminin
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa: Defective Collagen-7

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic bullous disorder of childhood: Incorrect. This condition presents with bullous lesions resembling a string of pearls or cluster of jewels appearance. It is an IgA-mediated immunobullous disorder manifesting in early childhood, not a congenital condition.

 

Option C. Congenital syphilis: Incorrect. Syphilitic pemphigus appears as a vesiculobullous disorder, and the VDRL test is the investigation of choice.

 

Option D. Neonatal pemphigus: Incorrect. This autoimmune disease occurs due to the transfer of maternal IgG autoantibodies to desmoglein 3. It is characterized by transient flaccid blisters and affects the skin and, rarely, mucous membranes.

 

Educational Objective:


Epidermolysis bullosa is a congenital mechanobullous disorder marked by blistering in response to minor trauma. It is vital to recognize this to differentiate from other vesiculobullous conditions and manage accordingly.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin


The presence of multiple nodulocystic lesions suggests a diagnosis of severe acne, specifically nodular acne or acne conglobata. Isotretinoin is the first-line drug for treating severe acne due to its effectiveness in reducing sebaceous gland size, decreasing sebum production, and minimizing inflammation.

 

Key considerations when using isotretinoin:

 

  • Teratogenicity: Isotretinoin is highly teratogenic and absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women, women planning to become pregnant, and breastfeeding mothers.
  • Pregnancy Testing: For females of childbearing age, two negative pregnancy tests are required before starting isotretinoin. Monthly pregnancy tests should be performed during treatment.
  • Baseline and Ongoing Monitoring: Baseline serum lipids, liver enzymes (transaminases), and complete blood counts should be obtained before initiating isotretinoin. These tests should be monitored monthly for the first 3-6 months and then once every 3 months.

 

For acitretin (a systemic retinoid used in cutaneous psoriasis), female patients should avoid conception for at least 3 years after discontinuing treatment due to its long half-life and potential teratogenicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids:  Systemic steroids are not the primary treatment for nodulocystic acne and are typically reserved for specific inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Erythromycin:  Erythromycin is used in acne treatment, especially in mild to moderate cases, but it is not the drug of choice for severe nodulocystic acne.

 

Option D. Tetracycline:  Tetracyclines, like doxycycline or minocycline, can be used for moderate to severe acne but are generally less effective than isotretinoin for nodulocystic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotretinoin is the first-line treatment for severe nodulocystic acne due to its efficacy in reducing sebaceous gland activity and inflammation, but it requires careful monitoring due to its teratogenic effects and impact on serum lipids and liver enzymes.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

The patient's symptoms, combined with lab findings of anemia, hypercalcemia, elevated total protein, and low albumin, along with osteolytic lesions, are indicative of multiple myeloma. The CRAB criteria (hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, and Bone lesions) support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Metastatic breast cancer can present similarly but usually has a different primary site.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia but not the full CRAB criteria.

 

Option D. Milk Alkali Syndrome causes hypercalcemia and renal impairment but not the protein abnormalities or osteolytic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and bone lesions.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby comes with a complaint of failure to thrive and presents with skin lesions that improve on a gluten-free diet. Which of the following option is true regarding the child’s condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A + B is correct

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition characterized by a hypersensitivity to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, bread, rye, and oats (collectively known as BROW). In individuals with celiac disease, ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, resulting in symptoms like chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and failure to thrive in children. Extra-intestinal manifestations include dermatitis herpetiformis, a skin condition characterized by itchy, blistering skin lesions commonly found on the elbows, knees, and other bony prominences.

 

Diagnosis of celiac disease often involves serological testing for anti-tissue transglutaminase (TTG) antibodies, which are usually elevated in affected individuals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Severe acute malnutrition: This condition causes failure to thrive due to inadequate nutritional intake but lacks the gluten sensitivity or specific skin lesions seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be considered in young children presenting with failure to thrive and characteristic skin lesions, especially when these symptoms improve with a gluten-free diet. Serological tests, including TTG, are crucial for confirming the diagnosis and should guide the clinical management of these patients.

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text:
A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

 

In the absence of graft rejection, transplantation is financially advantageous for a patient with diabetic nephropathy. When compared to two years of dialysis, transplant surgery is less expensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graft survival rate is ~80-82% at the end of first year.

 

Option B. The life expectancy of a patient with diabetic nephropathy is not doubled post-transplant.

 

Option D. Chronic graft rejection following renal transplantation is referred to as chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) which consists of tubular atrophy, glomerulosclerosis, fibrosis of the renal interstitium, and fibrous thickening of the arteries.

 

HLA mismatching, acute episodes of graft rejection, age mismatch between donor and recipient, smoking, and acute episodes of graft rejection are risk factors that put a recipient at risk for long-term graft rejection. Treatment is difficult and no significant improvement has been seen over last 10 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal transplantation becomes cost-effective after the second year post-transplant for diabetic nephropathy patients compared to ongoing dialysis. This consideration, coupled with improved quality of life and potential prolongation of life expectancy, makes it a favorable option for suitable candidates.

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulointerstitial nephritis

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis, also known as acute allergic interstitial nephritis, is often caused by an allergic reaction to medications such as antibiotics. In this scenario, the patient had a fever and sore throat and was subsequently treated with antibiotics, likely from the penicillin group. Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics are common culprits in causing type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, leading to the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria). This condition is also associated with the presence of WBC casts in the urine, indicating inflammation of the renal interstitium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with RBC casts rather than WBC casts and does not involve eosinophiluria. It follows a streptococcal infection and involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

 

Option C. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to glomerulonephritis. It is not typically associated with eosinophiluria and primarily presents with RBC casts.

 

Option D. Rhabdomyolysis: Rhabdomyolysis involves the breakdown of muscle tissue, leading to the release of muscle contents into the bloodstream, including myoglobin, which can cause renal damage. It is characterized by elevated creatine kinase levels and does not present with eosinophiluria or WBC casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

questions.text: Among the following which is considered as water borne hepatitis virus? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Hepatitis A virus

 

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is considered waterborne because it is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route. 
  • Out of the five major types of hepatitis viruses, only Hepatitis A and E are transmitted via the feco-oral route. 
  • This means they can be transmitted through contaminated water and food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis B is not waterborne. Hepatitis B is transmitted through sexual contact, needle syringes, parenteral route, and blood (including blood products). 

 

Option C. Hepatitis C virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis C is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual contact, needle sharing, and blood. 

 

Option D. Hepatitis D virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis D is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual, parenteral (needles), and blood routes, similar to Hepatitis B and C

 

Educational Objective:

 

Public Health Classification of Water Borne Diseases

questions.text: A 25yr old woman came to OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale, and investigations show a HB of 5mg/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count ? (take normal Hb as 15mg/dl) (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Corrected reticulocyte count (CRC)= reticulocyte % X (actual Hb/normal Hb)

 

CRC= 9 X 5/15 = 3%

 

CRC can also be calculated using hematocrit

 

CRC= Reticulocyte % X (Actual PCV/ normal PCV )

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) adjusts the observed reticulocyte percentage to reflect the degree of anemia by using the patient's actual hemoglobin compared to a normal hemoglobin level.

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is crucial for assessing bone marrow response in anemic patients, providing insight into whether the bone marrow is responding appropriately to the anemia. This is particularly important in managing patients with iron deficiency anemia to monitor recovery or response to therapy.

choices.text: POP for 3 months

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for two months. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

Explanation:

 

The next line of management in a 50-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is an endometrial biopsy. This is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, especially in a peri-menopausal woman.

 

Indications for Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Peri-menopausal women with AUB.
  • Hyperestrogenic states like obesity or tamoxifen treatment with thickened endometrium on transvaginal sonography (TVS).
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound findings of endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.

 

Methods of Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Curettage
  • Aspiration biopsy using Pipelle or Vibra aspirator

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LNG-IUCD: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD) is a treatment option but should be considered after ruling out malignancy.

 

Option B. POP for 3 months: Progestin-only pills (POP) can be used to manage AUB, but endometrial sampling should be done first to rule out malignancy.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but is considered after other management options and ruling out malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In peri-menopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, the first step is to perform endometrial sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy before considering other treatment modalities.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg184

choices.text: Mullerian agenesis
Gonadal dysgenesis
Turner syndrome
Testicular feminization syndrome

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mullerian agenesis

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.
  • Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • As ovaries are present, normal secondary sexual characters will develop

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis patients present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters poorly developed breasts

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters and short stature will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. The ovaries are streak ovaries

 

Option D. Testicular feminization syndrome: Testicular feminization syndrome also known as androgen insensitivity syndrome has a karyotype of 46XY. Secondary sexual characters like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

 

Educational Objective:


Mullerian agenesis is characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, with normal ovarian function leading to normal breast and pubic hair development.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

 

Fibrinolytic therapy, also known as thrombolytic therapy, is used to dissolve blood clots. Sometimes, it is necessary to reverse the effects of fibrinolytic drugs, especially in cases of excessive bleeding.

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA):

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is an antifibrinolytic agent. It works by binding to plasminogen competitively, which prevents plasminogen from binding to fibrin and being converted to plasmin. Plasmin is an enzyme responsible for breaking down fibrin in blood clots. By inhibiting this process, EACA effectively stops fibrinolysis and stabilizes blood clots, reducing the risk of bleeding.
  • Clinical Use: EACA is used to treat conditions where fibrinolysis is excessive, such as after the administration of fibrinolytic drugs (e.g., streptokinase, alteplase).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine: Protamine is used to neutralize the anticoagulant effects of heparin. It is not effective against fibrinolytic agents. Protamine binds to heparin, forming a stable complex that neutralizes heparin's anticoagulant activity.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Streptokinase is itself a fibrinolytic agent used to dissolve clots. It works by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which then breaks down fibrin. Streptokinase would increase fibrinolysis, not inhibit it.

 

Option C. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by inhibiting thrombin and other clotting factors. It does not act as an antidote to fibrinolytic therapy. Heparin would actually increase the risk of bleeding if administered during fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the appropriate antidote for fibrinolytic therapy because it inhibits fibrinolysis by preventing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby stabilizing blood clots and reducing bleeding risks.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the following local anesthesia technique shown in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasociliary nerve

 

  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • Procedure: The needle is inserted 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. A maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected.
  • Use: This nerve block is used in procedures such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and the treatment of nasal bone fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: The anterior ethmoidal nerve is another branch of the ophthalmic nerve. It innervates the anterior and middle ethmoidal air cells and part of the nasal cavity, but it is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve: The sphenopalatine nerve, also known as the nasopalatine nerve, is a branch of the maxillary nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve). It supplies the nasal septum and the anterior part of the hard palate, but the described technique does not target this nerve.

 

Option D. Greater palatine nerve: The greater palatine nerve is also a branch of the maxillary nerve. It innervates the hard palate and the palatal gingiva, and is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasociliary nerve block involves inserting a needle superior and posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye and injecting a local anesthetic solution. This technique is primarily used for procedures involving the nasal area, such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and nasal bone fracture treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2413-2414

questions.text: Two distinct patient cohorts at AIIMS New Delhi are subjected to different treatments to monitor their post-treatment blood pressure levels. The groups do not have overlapping members. Which statistical test would best suit the analysis of the blood pressure differences between the two groups? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unpaired t test

 

  • In the provided situation, two distinct groups are under comparison, and therefore, the appropriate statistical analysis would involve employing a Student's t-test or an unpaired t-test.
  • T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired t test: Used when comparing the same group before and after an intervention, not suitable for independent groups.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means among three or more groups.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: Used for categorical data, not for comparing means of continuous data.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step → RT-PCR
  • Second step → Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

questions.text: All of the following can cause miosis except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Belladonna

 

Belladonna is plant (Atropa belladonna) from which atropine (Anticholinergic drug) is obtained. It causes mydriasis not miosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphates: Organophosphates cause miosis by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, which increases acetylcholine levels, resulting in overstimulation of muscarinic receptors.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine induces miosis by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system through opioid receptors, leading to pupil constriction.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug that causes miosis by directly activating muscarinic receptors in the eye.

 

Educational objective:

 

Miosis or pin point pupil is caused by:-

 

  • Organophosphate poisoning
  • Opioids like morphine
  • Phenol poisoning
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Cholinergic drugs like pilocarpine

 

Reference: KDT 8th/115,122,127,499

questions.text: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C-Hypothalamus

 

The image shows the midsagittal section of the brain. The wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus. The structure marked as C corresponds to the thalamus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus Callosum: It's a large white matter structure found deep within the brain, lying superiorly to the thalamus and under the cortex. It connects the two cerebral hemispheres.

 

  • The primary purpose of the corpus callosum is to integrate motor, sensory, and cognitive performances between the cerebral cortex on one side of the brain to the same region on the other side. Essentially, it allows for communication between the two hemispheres of the brain.

 

Option C. Pituitary Gland: It is a pea-sized structure that's located at the base of the brain, right below the hypothalamus.

 

  • Often referred to as the "master gland," the pituitary gland secretes hormones that control several other endocrine glands. It has an anterior and posterior portion, each releasing specific hormones. These hormones regulate various physiological processes, including growth, reproductive cycles, and stress response.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Located at the ventral part of the brain, below the occipital lobes and posterior to the brainstem.

 

  • The cerebellum is primarily responsible for coordination and fine-tuning of motor movements. It also plays roles in posture and balance, and there is increasing evidence that it's involved in cognitive functions and emotion regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothalamus is situated at the base of the brain, just below the thalamus and right above the pituitary gland. This plays a crucial role in many important functions, including releasing hormones, regulating body temperature, maintaining daily physiological cycles, controlling appetite, managing of sexual behavior, and responding to the feeling of being full (eating).

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature cystic teratoma

 

The specimen shows an ovarian mass with a tuft of hair in a cystic space, which is characteristic of a mature cystic teratoma. Key points about mature cystic teratomas include:

 

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors: They contain various types of tissues derived from the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts): Typically unilocular and contain sebaceous material, hair, and sometimes other tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and neural tissues.
  • Presentation: Most patients are asymptomatic, but they may present with an abdominal mass, acute pain due to torsion of the ovary, or rarely due to rupture of the cyst.
  • Treatment: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy is the treatment of choice for mature teratomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immature teratoma: These are malignant and contain immature embryonic tissues, often neuroectodermal. They usually occur in younger patients and are more aggressive.

 

Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains mucinous material and does not contain hair or other tissues.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains clear serous fluid and lacks the complex tissues found in teratomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are characterized by the presence of multiple tissue types such as hair, sebaceous material, and sometimes teeth or bone within a cystic ovarian mass.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug.

 

A misbranded drug will not produce the effect due to reasons like lesser dose, different molecules in it etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: are drugs with improper labelling, labeling from a fictitious company, with improper storage guidelines, or even partly or wholly substituted by another drug or substance.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: are drugs with unwanted substance, for example iron in Paracetamol.

 

Option C. unethical drug: The term unethical drug is not used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug that is labeled as containing a certain amount of an active ingredient but actually contains a different amount is considered misbranded. Misbranded drugs can lead to ineffective treatment and potential harm due to incorrect dosing.

questions.text: Most commonly implicated drug for causation of acute liver failure is? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracetamol

 

  • All the four drugs given Paracetamol, Valproate, Warfarin and Tetracyclines can cause hepatotoxicity. Paracetamol among these is the most common cause particularly in patients with liver disease and in alcoholics.
  • Paracetamol is the most common cause of acute liver failure in many countries, particularly in the context of overdose. It can cause severe hepatotoxicity, which can lead to acute liver failure, especially when taken in doses exceeding recommended levels or in individuals with certain risk factors (such as existing liver disease and chronic alcohol use etc.).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: While valproate can cause hepatotoxicity, it is less commonly associated with acute liver failure compared to paracetamol. It is more frequently a concern in certain populations, such as young children and individuals on multiple anticonvulsants.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is not commonly associated with acute liver failure. Its primary risk is bleeding due to its anticoagulant effects.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: High doses of tetracycline, especially the older formulations, can cause liver toxicity, but it is not the most common drug causing acute liver failure. Tetracycline-induced liver injury is now relatively rare due to the decreased use of high-dose intravenous forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is the most common drug implicated in the causation of acute liver failure, especially in the context of overdose and in individuals with risk factors like existing liver disease and chronic alcohol use.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/223

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

     

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation is a safety feature designed to release pressure when it exceeds a certain limit to prevent barotrauma to the patient. This valve typically releases at a pressure range of 30-40 cm of water (H2O). This pressure setting helps ensure that the air is delivered to the patient safely without causing excessive force that could damage the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.

questions.text: A male patient is being treated for a mood disorder. After starting a new medication, he experiences priapism, a prolonged, painful erection. The healthcare provider is considering changing the medication. Which drug is most likely responsible for causing priapism in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trazodone

 

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that is often used off-label for insomnia. It is known to cause priapism as a rare but serious side effect. Given that the patient has a mood disorder and experienced priapism, trazodone is the most likely culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. While sexual dysfunction is a potential side effect, it is not commonly associated with priapism.

 

Option C. Bupropion: This is an atypical antidepressant used for depression and smoking cessation. It is not commonly associated with priapism as a side effect.

 

Option D. Mirtazapine: This is another atypical antidepressant used for depression. It also has a low likelihood of causing priapism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trazodone is the most likely antidepressant to cause priapism among the listed options due to its known side effect profile. This serious condition necessitates careful monitoring and potentially switching medications to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After 5 months of treatment, he develops hyperpigmentation in the palms and soles. What is the most likely drug causing this? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emtricitabine

 

The most likely drug causing hyperpigmentation of the hands and soles is emtricitabine.

 

Emtricitabine is an anti-retroviral drug that acts by inhibiting nucleoside reverse transcriptase (NRTI). It is generally well-tolerated and has minimal toxic effects. One of the known adverse effects is hyperpigmentation of the skin, particularly in sun-exposed areas, as well as the palms and soles. Other side effects may include headache, vomiting, and nausea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nelfinavir: Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor that is more commonly associated with causing diarrhea or loose stools, which usually resolves within a month of starting treatment. It does not commonly cause hyperpigmentation.

 

Option C. Abacavir: Abacavir is another NRTI but is known for its potential to cause a life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome, which typically presents with fever, abdominal pain, and maculopapular rash. This reaction occurs within 6 weeks of starting the drug and requires immediate discontinuation. Hyperpigmentation is not a known side effect of Abacavir.

 

Option D. Zidovudine: Zidovudine is an NRTI associated with side effects like malaise, fatigue, myalgia, anorexia, and insomnia. It can also cause nail hyperpigmentation and bone marrow suppression, but it is not as strongly associated with hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles as emtricitabine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine is an NRTI that can cause hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles, especially in individuals on long-term antiretroviral therapy. It is essential to monitor patients for this side effect, although it is typically benign.

choices.text: Basal stent placement

questions.text: Interventional technique used for the management of cerebral aneurysm: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coiling

 

The management of cerebral aneurysms, particularly berry aneurysms, involves two primary interventional techniques: clipping and coiling.
