  • Coiling: This is an endovascular procedure where a catheter is inserted through the femoral artery and navigated to the aneurysm. Coils are then deployed into the aneurysm to induce thrombosis and prevent rupture. Coiling has lower morbidity and mortality rates compared to surgical clipping and is preferred if the aneurysm is accessible for endovascular treatment.
  • Clipping: This involves a craniotomy where the skull is opened, and a clip is placed at the neck of the aneurysm to isolate it from the circulation. While effective, it is more invasive compared to coiling.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Embolization: While embolization is used in various vascular interventions, it is not the preferred technique for managing cerebral aneurysms.

 

Option C. Basal stent placement: Stents may be used as an adjunct to coiling to support the coil mass and ensure complete occlusion of the aneurysm, but stent placement alone is not effective for managing aneurysms.

 

Option D. Balloon Angioplasty: This technique is used to dilate narrowed blood vessels but is not suitable for treating aneurysms as it can worsen the aneurysm by increasing the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred interventional technique for the management of cerebral aneurysms is endovascular coiling due to its lower morbidity and mortality compared to surgical clipping.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

 

The clinical presentation of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad associated with this condition includes:

 

  1. Intracranial diffuse calcifications
  2. Chorioretinitis
  3. Hydrocephalus

 

These features are clearly visible in the provided imaging, where multiple calcifications (white dots) are seen throughout the brain, which is typical of toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infection in a congenital context typically presents with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse intracranial calcifications. This means the calcifications are primarily located around the brain's ventricles rather than spread diffusely throughout.

 

 

Option C. Zika virus: Zika virus infection can lead to gray matter and white matter calcifications, which are distinct from the diffuse calcifications seen in toxoplasmosis. Zika is also associated with microcephaly and contractures, which are not noted in this case.

 

Option D. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can present with various symptoms such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing impairment, but it is not typically associated with intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to memorize is that the triad of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Remember:

 

  • Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection
  • Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis
  • Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition commonly seen in infants where there is hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to a narrowing of the pyloric canal. This condition presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding, typically around the age of 3 to 6 weeks. The physical finding of an "olive-shaped" mass in the abdomen is characteristic of this condition, which represents the enlarged pyloric muscle.

 

The X-ray findings in pyloric stenosis often show a single bubble sign due to gastric distension without further passage of air into the intestines. This is because the pyloric canal is obstructed, preventing stomach contents from moving into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: This term is more general and can refer to various types of obstructions within the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of an infant with projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass, this is not specific enough and does not pinpoint the pyloric obstruction characteristic of pyloric stenosis.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is characterized by a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, which is not present in this case. This condition leads to bilious vomiting due to a congenital closure or absence of the duodenal lumen, distinguishing it from pyloric stenosis, which presents with non-bilious vomiting.

 

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia would show a "triple bubble" sign on imaging, which indicates obstruction beyond the duodenum in the jejunum. This would also present with bilious vomiting, unlike the non-bilious vomiting seen in pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

choices.text: Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased
Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with diabetes has high increased LDL and VLDL because of (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased


In diabetes, there is either a deficiency of insulin or insulin resistance. Insulin normally inhibits hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). When insulin is deficient or not working properly, HSL activity increases while LPL activity decreases. HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue, releasing fatty acids into circulation. Increased HSL activity leads to more triglycerides being broken down. Meanwhile, decreased LPL activity reduces the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins from the bloodstream. This combined effect results in elevated levels of VLDL and subsequently LDL in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, these two enzymes are regulated in opposite directions. While HSL is increased, LPL is decreased due to the lack of insulin's regulatory effect.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased: This is the opposite of what occurs in diabetes. This pattern would be seen in a fed state with normal insulin action, not in diabetes.

 

Option D. Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, HSL is increased, not decreased. While LPL is indeed decreased in diabetes, both enzymes are not decreased.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) activity is increased while lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is decreased due to insulin deficiency or resistance, leading to elevated levels of VLDL and LDL.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: Maximum brain growth occurs at which year of life? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 years

 

Brain growth reaches its maximum around 2 years of age. This early and rapid growth phase is crucial for the development of cognitive and motor skills, and it aligns with significant milestones in early childhood development, such as language acquisition, sensory processing, and coordination. The early years are critical for brain development, as synaptic connections are formed at a rapid pace during this time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 years: At 6 years of age, the lymphoid tissues reach their maximum size. The lymphoid system includes the tonsils, adenoids, and other components of the immune system, which are prominent in early childhood to protect against infections.

 

Option C. 10 years: This age is not specifically associated with peak growth in any of the major developmental domains mentioned (brain, lymphoid, somatic, or puberty).

 

Option D. 12 years: This age marks the peak growth for somatic (body) growth and the onset of puberty. During this period, there is a significant increase in height and secondary sexual characteristics as the body undergoes maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum brain growth occurs by 2 years of age, emphasizing the importance of early childhood for brain development.

 

Remember:

 

  • Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3

 

The insight scale is graded from 1 to 5. In this scenario, the patient recognizes that there's something wrong with him mentally, which signifies some level of insight. However, he attributes it to the summer season, an external factor. This corresponds to a score of 3, which is recognition of a mental illness but blaming it on external causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Insight is graded from 1 to 5.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 967.

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically stored in the lowest compartment of the ILR? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV

 

In an Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR), vaccines are stored at specific temperatures to maintain their potency. The lowest compartment of the ILR is the coldest part, which is optimal for storing vaccines that require the coldest temperatures. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is stored in the lowest compartment because it requires the coldest storage conditions to remain effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penta: Pentavalent vaccine (which protects against five diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b) does not require the lowest temperature and is generally stored in the middle compartments.

 

Option B. DPT: The DPT vaccine (Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus) does not need to be stored in the coldest compartment and is kept in the upper or middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Option C. Hep B: The Hepatitis B vaccine also does not require the lowest storage temperature and is kept in the middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) should be stored in the lowest compartment of the Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR) due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptin

 

The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin.

 

Leptin is a peptide hormone released from adipocytes

 

Leptin plays an important role in controlling the adipose tissue and food intake.

 

Actions of leptin:

 

  • Acts on hypothalamus and inhibits the feeding center, resulting in stoppage of food intake
  • Stimulates the metabolic reactions involved in utilization of fat stored in adipose tissue for energy. Thus, the circulating leptin level informs the brain about the energy storage and the necessity to regulate metabolic reactions, food intake and body weight
  • Elevated leptin levels might have a permissive effect on the pubertal process and pubertal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH: Incorrect as GnRH directly stimulates the secretion of LH and FSH, which are critical for puberty but not considered permissive.

 

Option C. Insulin: While it plays a supportive role in general growth and development, it is not specifically permissive for the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. GH: Growth hormone is vital for growth and development during puberty but does not have a direct permissive role in the initiation of puberty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty, indicating to the hypothalamus that sufficient energy reserves are available for the safe progression of reproductive development. This hormone essentially "permits" the initiation of puberty when energy conditions are met.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.

 

Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: On the 5th day after coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG), a patient develops rapid breathing and low blood pressure. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute respiratory failure

 

The symptoms of rapid breathing (tachypnea) and hypotension in a patient on the 5th day post-CABG suggest acute respiratory failure, commonly caused by lung collapse (atelectasis). This complication occurs frequently in the postoperative period and is classified as type 3 respiratory failure.

 

  • Risk Factors: The likelihood of developing atelectasis is higher after general anesthesia, upper abdominal, or thoracic surgery. Reduced lung expansion due to pain and restricted mobility are contributing factors.
  • Signs and Symptoms: Patients often present with decreased oxygen saturation, tachypnea, and diminished breath sounds with a bronchial character on auscultation.
  • Management Strategies: Early intervention, including mobilization, deep breathing exercises, the use of an incentive spirometer, and chest physiotherapy, can resolve atelectasis within 24-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sepsis: Sepsis would need to be confirmed with clinical evidence of infection and an increased SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) score by at least 2 points. In the absence of a clear infection or systemic symptoms, sepsis is less likely in this context.

 

Option B. Acute kidney failure: Defined by reduced urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/h over 6-12 hours) and increased serum creatinine (>1.5 times the baseline or >0.3 mg/dL), acute kidney injury typically occurs later or as a secondary issue and is not the most immediate concern in this case.

 

Option D. Acute cardiac failure: This condition would present with signs such as hypotension, rapid heart rate, and reduced perfusion, evidenced by cold, clammy extremities. Without specific indications of heart dysfunction, acute respiratory failure is a more probable cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atelectasis is a frequent postoperative respiratory issue following thoracic or upper abdominal surgeries, presenting with symptoms like tachypnea and low oxygen levels. Early mobilization and breathing exercises are crucial for management and recovery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following interventions is not typically performed in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet transfusion

 

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically performed as an immediate intervention for variceal bleeding. Platelets are responsible for blood clotting, but variceal bleeding is primarily caused by the rupture of dilated blood vessels (varices) in the esophagus or stomach, which is related to portal hypertension.
  • Platelet transfusions are usually considered when a patient with liver cirrhosis has significant thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) or when there is an underlying bleeding disorder. However, they are not the primary treatment for variceal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arrange PRBC (packed red blood cell) transfusion: PRBC transfusion is often necessary to replace lost blood and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. Active variceal bleeding can lead to significant blood loss, and transfusion of red blood cells is a crucial part of resuscitation.

 

Option C. IV Octreotide: IV Octreotide is commonly administered in cases of active variceal bleeding. Octreotide is a medication that helps reduce portal pressure by constricting blood vessels, including those in the varices. This can help control the bleeding until more definitive treatment, such as endoscopy or interventional radiology procedures, can be performed.

 

Option D. Urgent Endoscopy: Urgent endoscopy, typically performed within 12-24 hours, is a critical intervention in the management of variceal bleeding. During endoscopy, a gastroenterologist can identify the source of bleeding and perform interventions such as band ligation or sclerotherapy to stop the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of variceal bleeding:

 

  • Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy.
  • Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy.
  • Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding.
  • Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5yrs back. His ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for patient? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC Cardioversion.

 

The given ECG shows wide QRS complex with no P wave suggesting the diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia. Clinical features of exercise intolerance and the presence of ischemic heart disease also support the diagnosis of VT. Since patient hemodynamically unstable, next best step is DC Cardioversion. For stable patients, amiodarone is given intravenously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine and D. Lidocaine: These are antiarrhythmic drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias but are less appropriate in acute, hemodynamically unstable VT where immediate cardioversion is preferred.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Typically used for heart rate control in atrial fibrillation and not suitable for acute VT, especially in the context of hemodynamic instability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with ventricular tachycardia and signs of hemodynamic instability, DC Cardioversion is the recommended treatment to quickly restore normal heart rhythm. Pharmacological treatments like amiodarone may be considered post-cardioversion for rhythm stabilization in stable patients.

questions.text: What was ETDRS study related to? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diabetic Macular edema

 

  • Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a clinical trial.
  • The study investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
  • The study demonstrated that focal photocoagulation was beneficial in treating diabetic macular edema.
  • The study recommended that eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal artery occlusion: Not the focus of the ETDRS; this condition involves sudden, painless vision loss due to an occlusion in the central retinal artery.

 

Option C. Primary open angle glaucoma: Not related to the ETDRS, which did not address glaucoma treatments or outcomes.

 

Option D. Non-infectious uveitis: Also unrelated to the ETDRS, as the study was specific to diabetic retinopathy and macular edema, not inflammatory eye diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ETDRS study established the beneficial effects of photocoagulation in treating diabetic macular edema, recommending it as an early treatment option to prevent vision loss in patients with clinically significant macular edema.

questions.text: A child presented with intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a “crumpled paper appearance.” What is your best diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The Ans. is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within macrophages, resulting in cells that have a characteristic "crumpled paper" appearance when viewed under a microscope. The presence of these cells, along with symptoms like intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GALT enzyme: This enzyme is related to Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. It does not present with a "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow biopsies, nor is it associated with the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder due to a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase. It typically involves muscle weakness and cardiomegaly but does not produce the "crumpled paper" cells seen in bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: This is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. The characteristic cells in Niemann-Pick disease have a "foamy" appearance, not the "crumpled paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (II CN), and is not involved in the movement of the eyeball.

 

The optic nerve is primarily responsible for carrying visual information from the retina to the brain. It is not directly involved in controlling eye movements, but it is crucial for vision itself.

 

The nerves marked in the image are:

 

  • A- Optic nerve (II CN)
  • B- Oculomotor nerve (III CN)
  • C- Abducens nerve (VI CN)
  • D- Trochlear nerve (IV CN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve (III CN): The oculomotor nerve controls the majority of the eye's movements. It innervates several extraocular muscles responsible for moving the eye in various directions, including upward, downward, and medially. It also controls the pupil's constriction and the accommodation of the lens for focusing on near objects. It innervates all extraocular muscles except - lateral rectus and superior oblique.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve (VI CN): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye outward or laterally. It allows for abduction of the eye, helping to look away from the nose.

 

Option D. Trochlear nerve (IV CN): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for depressing the eye and intorsion (rotation inward). It helps in downward and inward eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is a form of cell-mediated immune response that occurs typically 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. This response is primarily mediated by T-helper 1 (Th1) cells which secrete a variety of cytokines, including Interferon gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is crucial in activating macrophages and enhancing their microbicidal activity, which is a key component of the DTH response. This type of hypersensitivity is important in defense against intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) - IL-2 is primarily involved in the activation and proliferation of T cells but is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) - IL-12 plays a role in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and can promote IFN-γ production, but it is not the direct mediator of DTH.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) - IL-4 is associated with the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and promotes humoral immunity, which is not involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

questions.text: One mother had brought her child for evaluation of diphtheria in which the child had low-grade fever, pseudomembranes over the tonsils, and one sibling is fully immunized. What will be the prophylaxis given to her sibling? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The Ans. is Erythromycin. In cases where a household member is diagnosed with diphtheria, all close contacts, including fully immunized siblings, should be given prophylactic treatment regardless of their immunization status.

 

The recommended prophylaxis for contacts is oral Erythromycin for seven days or a single dose of benzathine penicillin. This approach aims to prevent the spread of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and the development of active diphtheria lesions in contacts, even if they are asymptomatic and immunized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria booster single dose: A booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid is recommended for previously immunized individuals who are diagnosed with diphtheria but are asymptomatic. This does not apply to the contact sibling who is already fully immunized and not infected.

 

Option C. Diphtheria toxoid full course: A full course of the diphtheria toxoid is not necessary for a fully immunized sibling who is a contact. This option would be considered for individuals who are not up-to-date with their diphtheria vaccinations.

 

Option D. Nothing is required: This option is incorrect because all household contacts of a diphtheria case should receive prophylactic treatment to prevent possible infection and transmission, even if they are asymptomatic and fully immunized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fully immunized close contacts of a diphtheria case, the recommended prophylaxis is a seven-day course of oral Erythromycin or a single dose of benzathine penicillin.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

choices.text: Congenital absence of seminal vesicles
Obstruction in the ejaculatory duct

questions.text: Fructose is absent in the seminal fluid, which of the following statements is true regarding this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A and  B

 

Fructose is absent in seminal fluid in cases of congenital absence of the seminal vesicles and obstruction of the ejaculatory duct.

 

  • The ejaculatory duct is formed by the fusion of the ductus deferens and the duct of the seminal vesicle. A major portion of the semen volume is contributed by the seminal vesicles.
  • Seminal fluid is alkaline and protects sperm from acidity in prostatic secretions and in the vagina.
  • Fructose in the seminal fluid provides an energy source for sperm. If the seminal vesicles are absent, or if there is an obstruction in the ejaculatory duct, seminal fluid analysis will show low ejaculate volume, oligospermia or azoospermia, low pH, and the absence of fructose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital absence of seminal vesicles: True, as fructose is produced by the seminal vesicles. Their congenital absence leads to a lack of fructose in the semen.

 

Option B. Obstruction in the ejaculatory duct: True, as an obstruction at this level would prevent the fructose-containing seminal fluid from entering the ejaculate.

 

Option D. None: This option is incorrect because fructose can be absent due to both congenital absence of seminal vesicles and obstruction of the ejaculatory duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fructose is an essential component of seminal fluid, produced by the seminal vesicles. Its absence in the semen can indicate either a congenital absence of seminal vesicles or an obstruction of the ejaculatory duct.

choices.text: Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months amenorrhea. Her FSH and LH were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

 

Explanation

 

  • Since LH and FSH are elevated above the normal value, the possibility of a pregnancy can be ruled out as FSH and LH levels fall to very low levels in pregnancy
  • The first step in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea after ruling out pregnancy is to do a progesterone challenge test i.e. to see if she bleeds after a challenge of progesterone.
  • If she bleeds, the diagnosis is anovulation like in PCOS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estimate serum estradiol values: Serum estradiol level measurement has no role in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea

 

Option D. Do a urine pregnancy test: FSH levels in pregnancy are very very low so pregnancy is unlikely; otherwise the most common cause of secondary amenorrhoea is pregnancy

 

Option C. Check USG for Polycystic ovaries: This is done if the patient bleeds following progesterone withdrawal as it determines the cause of anovular cycles

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is defined as a period of amenorrhoea of 6 months
  • Pregnancy needs to be ruled out
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea after ruling out pregnancy is anovulation (PCOS) which can be determined by the progesterone withdrawal test

 

Ref: Page no 457, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). All the following can be used for treatment except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptokinase

 

In the management of NSTEMI, the focus is on antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy rather than fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase. Streptokinase is specifically used in the treatment of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where there is a fibrin-rich thrombus completely occluding a coronary artery. NSTEMI, in contrast, involves a partial occlusion by a platelet-rich thrombus, and fibrinolytics are generally not recommended because they are less effective and could potentially increase the risk of bleeding without significant benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: As a foundational antiplatelet agent, aspirin is used in both STEMI and NSTEMI to reduce platelet aggregation and further thrombus formation.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: This is another antiplatelet drug that is used in the management of both STEMI and NSTEMI as part of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) along with aspirin to provide greater protection against thrombotic events.

 

Option D. Prasugrel: Similar to clopidogrel, prasugrel is used in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) management, including NSTEMI, especially when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is planned, due to its potent antiplatelet effects. (Prasugrel is given peri-procedurally).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21e chap 118/3518

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of evets occurring after p wave in ECG? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

 

The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, i.e.: - a wave in JVP (right atrial filling) -› First heart sound (closure of AV valve) -› T wave in ECG (ventricular systole) -> Rapid filling of ventricles.

 

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of events following the P wave in an ECG is: a wave in JVP, first heart sound, T wave (Electrical activity first i.e. repolarization) followed by rapid filling of ventricles (Mechanical activity i.e. relaxation).

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

 

The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

 

Toxic megacolon is a severe condition characterized by acute colonic distension and systemic toxicity. It is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. Patients with toxic megacolon can present with high fever, abdominal pain, and a history of bloody diarrhea, which aligns with the patient's symptoms in this case. The abdominal X-ray shows transverse colonic dilation > 6 cm, which is a characteristic finding in toxic megacolon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a condition in which a portion of the bowel twists on itself, leading to obstruction and ischemia. While it can cause abdominal pain, it typically does not present with the same systemic symptoms seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Ogilvie syndrome: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is characterized by marked colonic dilation without a mechanical obstruction. It can cause abdominal pain and distension but does not typically present with a history of bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestine. While it can be seen on imaging studies, it is not a specific diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.

 

A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed to find the cause of death of a person brought dead to the casualty. It showed abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage and contused tissues in the neck. The cause of death is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Throttling

 

The description of the autopsy findings, including abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage, and contused tissues in the neck, typically indicates death resulting from external pressure on the neck. Throttling is the act of applying pressure to the neck, often by external force or someone’s hands, which can lead to these specific injuries.

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck.

 

Autopsy finding

 

External Findings:

 

  • Neck abrasions and bruises, often near the laryngeal prominence and jawline.
  • Signs of asphyxia: cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu’s spot, and bleeding from the nose and ears.
  • Finger bruises, usually 1.5–2 cm in size.
  • Extent depends on factors like pressure, assailant’s nails, and victim’s resistance.
  • Thumb marks are more prominent, and multiple abrasions may result from victim’s struggle.

 

Internal Findings:

 

  • Muscle tears.
  • Tongue damage.
  • Inward hyoid bone fracture.
  • Thyroid cartilage fracture.
  • Carotid sheath laceration and carotid artery damage.

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling as bruises and abrasions on the neck is seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: In the case of hanging, there will be a ligature mark, which is not mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Strangulation is a very generalized term used to describe deaths due to violent asphyxia. Eg- ligature strangulation, throttling etc. Since Throttling is already given in option B we can consider option C strangulation as ligature strangulation. It cannot be the answer as ligature mark is not seen.

 

Option D. Mugging: In mugging cases, the assailant typically compresses or squeezes the victim’s neck by using the crook of their elbow or knee. While a victim killed by this method may exhibit signs of asphyxia, a neck examination may not reveal any signs of violence because the compression is applied using the soft muscles of the arm or leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing abrasions, contusions, and fractures in the neck structures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Natural history of disease refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment. It has two phases, a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

 

 

  • The period of pre-pathogenesis is before the onset of disease in humans.
  • An interaction between the agent, host and the environment occurs in this phase before the pathogenesis.
  • It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host.
  • The exposure is a microorganism in an infectious disease. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibres or components in tobacco smoke.
  • Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • The period of pathogenesis starts after the disease process has been triggered and pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it.
  • It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death, or disability.
  • The subclinical or asymptomatic period between exposure and onset of symptoms is called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases.
  • The onset of clinical symptoms is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.
  • Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.
  • It is a part of tertiary prevention like providing callipers for walking patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

 

Educational Objective:
